Slowpitch softball: 7 innings (5 in certain college games)

Slowpitch softball: Equipment

Fastpitch softball: 12 or 11 inches (305 or 279 mm) in circumference, less dense than a baseball
Slowpitch softball: often same as fastpitch softball, special 14 or 16 inch (356 or 406 mm) balls rarely used, less dense than a baseball

Fastpitch softball: No longer than 42 inches (1067 mm). Must be made of wood at the professional level; may be made of aluminum in high school and college.
Slowpitch softball: No longer than 34 inches (864 mm). Most commonly made of composite materials, also aluminum, though wooden bats may be used

Fastpitch softball: No, except in youth leagues such as Little League
Slowpitch softball: Yes, all levels under ISF, NSA and ASA. Used on a state-by-state basis in high school.

Fastpitch softball: Variable distance from home plate is mandatory in professional and university leagues and optional in youth leagues. Many youth leagues, such as Little League, use a constant distance from home plate.
Slowpitch softball: Variable distance from home plate, depending on the individual field. (maximum of 250 ft/76 m)

Fastpitch softball: 60 feet, 6 inches (18.44 m)
Slowpitch softball: Varies by level: 40 feet (12.19 m) (women's amateur), 43 feet (13.11 m) (women's high school (some states still play at 40), college and international) or 46 feet (14.02 m) (men)

Fastpitch softball: Raised sloping mound, radius of 9 feet (2.7 m), maximum height 10 inches (25 cm)
Slowpitch softball: Flat circle, radius of 8 feet (2.4 m), marked with a white chalk circle

Fastpitch softball: Nine
Slowpitch softball: Nine (before 1946, ten)

Fastpitch softball: In some leagues, one designated hitter (DH) may bat in place of a fielder (usually only in place of the pitcher, but may bat for any defensive player under United States high school rules. Under U.S. collegiate rules, the starting pitcher may also be named the DH--P/DH on the lineup card--and be substituted for as if he were two different players.)
Slowpitch softball: One designated player (DP) may bat in place of a fielder.

Fastpitch softball: No player substituted for may return to the game, including the replaced player if the DH takes a defensive position. EXCEPTION: Under high school rules in the United States, a player may be substituted for and return to the game once (this does not include "courtesy runners" for the pitcher and catcher). A pitcher who leaves the game may return, but only as a fielder (not the pitcher or DH).
Slowpitch softball: Free defensive substitutions, provided each player occupies the same position in the batting order. Except in high school, if the DP takes a defensive position, the replaced player cannot return to the game.

Fastpitch softball: Batter is not out unless bunting.
Slowpitch softball: Batter is not out unless bunting.

Fastpitch softball: Awarded first base unless swing, pitch in strike zone, or no attempt made to avoid being hit.
Slowpitch softball: Awarded first base unless swing, pitch in strike zone, or attempt made to intentionally be hit, although this is rarely called by the umpire.

Slowpitch softball: Runner

Fastpitch softball: Allowed at any time the ball is live (i.e. when "Time" is not called).
Slowpitch softball: Allowed once the ball leaves the pitcher's hand; runners may not leave base if the pitcher has the ball within the circle.

Fastpitch softball: Same rules as for base stealing.
Slowpitch softball: Same rules as for base stealing.

Fastpitch softball: Pitching
Slowpitch softball: Pitching

Fastpitch softball: Any method; in practice, usually overhand.
Slowpitch softball: Underhand; no speed or arc restrictions.

Fastpitch softball: Most infractions punished as a balk. In United States high school baseball, the ball is automatically dead, and all runners advance one base. At the college and professional levels the ball is not automatically dead. If the batter hits a balk pitch and all runners advance at least one base, the balk is ignored, otherwise the balk is enforced.
Slowpitch softball: The ball remains live. If the batter reaches base successfully and all runners advance, no penalty; otherwise, the play is negated, the pitch attempt is automatically a ball and runners advance one base.
